description: This two-semester second-level writing course aims to guide students to (1) practice basic academic writing convention, (2) sharpen analytical essay writing skills, (3) enhance essay coherence and cohesion, and (4) develop a clear writing style. The course will familiarize students with proper academic language and convention to compose five-paragraph short essays on the following five modes of writing: argumentation, definition, causal analysis, process analysis, and comparison and contrast. In addition to the different analytical modes of writing, the course will introduce students to organizing and editing strategies to fine-tune their essay writing. On the one hand, students will learn how to apply principles of coherence and cohesion in their writing to maintain consistent claims and to offer logical transitions at the levels of ideas, sentences, and paragraphs. On the other hand, students will learn how to develop a clear writing style by avoiding common sentence errors and improving concision and specificity in word choice and sentence formation.
goals: To help students student develop their ability to express themselves in writing essays in English
To help students write various kinds of essays in a well-organized manner
syllabus:
**Course Outline:** The Objectives.

This course is designed to help students **cultivate** **their ability to express themselves in written English**. At first, **the basics of essay writing** will be presented in an easy-to-follow progression of lessons and activities by way of **short lectures****, straightforward advice and practical assignments** (in class and for written homework). The major concern at this time will be **free-writing practice and techniques**, in order to develop the students’ writing fluency and to **encourage creativity and individual style**, and subsequently **giving the tools** they will need to approach writing well-constructed essays with confidence.

\`           Thereafter, the students will begin writing **five paragraph essays** in earnest in **several genres** including **descriptive/creative, the TOEFL independent writing task**, **film criticism** and **argumentative discourse**. By the end of the course, every student should be able to write a well-organised, focused and logical five-paragraph English essay in a number of genres including creative, descriptive, argumentative, and film-criticism, as well as gaining proficiency in exam situations.

Finally, **extracurricular writing is encouraged** at this stage and will be rewarded with extra grade! 

**What You Need:** The Necessities.

**Materials:** One **“Writing Journal”,** which is to be used for note-taking, free-writing, homework assignments, essay writing and optional writing practice.

**\*Optional Textbook:** Wyrick, Jean (2012). _Steps to Writing Well. 12th Edition_ Colorado State University: Wadsworth.

**Guidelines and Requirements:** The Rules.

1.  Punctual attendance is required. Please be on time. It’s polite. **Talk to or email me** if you have a problem attending or couldn’t attend class.
2.  **Actively participate** in class discussions and writing activities.
3.  You need to **submit** homework **_several times_** during the semester.
4.  **Homework** assignments and **essays** must be done **on time**.
5.  Smartphones, tablets, computers, etc. must be **turned off** unless needed in class.
6.  **No eating** during class, but drinks **are allowed**.
7.  **Extracurricular Writing Practice:** Besides homework and free-writing assignments, students are **encouraged** to practice writing at every opportunity. They should do so in their “Writing Journals”, and will be gladly reviewed and assessed by the lecturer.

**Grading Policy****:** The Business. 

Students’ term grades will be given based on their performances on the following aspects:

1.  Attendance + Participation: 10%
2.  Classroom Activities Writing Practice: 10%
3.  Prewriting and Essay Plan Homework: 10%
4.  TOEFL Mid-term essay: 10%
5.  Three long essays: 20% each

(i.e., descriptive/creative, film criticism and argumentative)
